questions.question: A transaction is a unit of program execution that may access multiple data items.
The ACID properties include Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability.
In a read‑only transaction the database is updated but not read.
A transaction that fails after an update to one record must still leave that record unchanged in the database until recovery.
Durability guarantees that once a transaction commits, its changes will persist even if the system crashes afterwards.
Isolation requires that two concurrent transactions never read each other’s intermediate values.
Lost update problems occur when two transactions write to the same record concurrently without proper synchronization.
The temporary update (dirty‑read) problem is solved by allowing a transaction to read uncommitted data from another transaction.
A consistency violation can happen during the execution of a transaction but must be resolved before it commits.
An active transaction that aborts will always leave the database in a partially committed state.
The log record for a write operation normally contains the old value and the new value of the data item.
Recovery can be performed by redoing only those transactions that have already committed before a crash.
The commit point of a transaction is reached once all its database operations are executed and the changes are recorded in the log.
A system failure such as a power loss is considered a media failure.
When two transactions run concurrently, the database must always show a consistent snapshot of all tables after each transaction completes.
If a transaction’s log record is missing for one of its writes, recovery will never be able to undo that change if it did not commit.
The concurrency control scheme called locking can prevent lost update problems by ensuring exclusive write access.
A deadlock occurs when two transactions hold locks on each other and wait for a resource that is held by the other.
The consistency requirement only concerns primary key integrity constraints.
